awd_titl_txt: RTG: Research Training Group in Algebra, Algebraic Geometry, and Number Theory
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will provide training through research involvement for students and postdoctoral associates in the areas of algebra, algebraic geometry, and number theory.  These are some of the oldest branches of mathematics.  Current research in these areas is a fascinating mixture of the old and the new: the study of longstanding challenging problems using very modern techniques that intertwine viewpoints from all three areas.  Geometry flowered in the third and fourth centuries BC with the study of conic sections by the Greeks; more recent approaches related these geometric objects to quadratic equations.  Algebraic geometry is the more general study of geometric objects using polynomials.  Number theory is also a very old subject with a history that predates even that of geometry; it is now closely related to algebraic geometry via the study of polynomials with integer coefficients.  Research in these fields has had a wide range of applications from elementary particle physics to cybersecurity. 

This Research Training Group will help to communicate the excitement of these research areas to students and to foster new research among faculty, postdoctoral associates, and students.  The focus of this project is to involve undergraduate students, graduate students, and postdoctoral associates in common research.  The investigators plan to achieve these goals by running a colloquium series, by offering topics courses to students, by running a yearly workshop and a yearly conference, and by organizing reading courses among students and postdoctoral associates on topics of current interest.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual merits: 
The Research Training Group in Algebra, Algebraic Geometry and Number Theory at UC San Diego is a large and very active group. Faculty expertise is very broad and includes such diverse areas as Lie groups and algebras, discrete subgroups, non-commutative algebra, moduli and Hodge theory, higher dimensional algebraic geometry and Mori theory, Gromov-Witten and Donaldson invariants, L-functions and arithmetic statistics, p-adic analysis and geometry, ergodic theory and homogeneous dynamics, automorphic forms, representation theory and the Langlands program, Iwasawa theory. Faculty regularly supervise a good number of post-docs and graduate and undergraduate students.

Broader impacts: With the award of the RTG grant, the group implemented many new activities. These activities enhanced collaboration and exchanges of ideas within the group as well as with outside mathematicians. These included the RTG colloquium, with general talks, and yearly conferences, where talks were at the cutting edge of research. They included topics courses and a very large number of reading/working seminars where members introduced each other to different subjects. They included graduate workshops where graduate students lectured on their research or subjects they were learning. They also included a reading program for undergraduates, mentored by graduate students under the supervision of a faculty member. Post-docs participated in all activities, including mentoring students and organizing seminars. Participants also traveled to outside conferences and workshops. All graduate students and post-docs were recruited to good positions in academia or industry upon completion of their work at UCSD.
